III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
1

rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth had carpet burns from an incident at the facility. There are
concerns with staff member forcing drugs down someone's throat.
Investigation Interviews:
On 01/21/2025 an unsuccessful attempt was made to contact
Complainant. A voicemail message was left requesting a return
call with any additional information or concerns. On 01/23/2025
Complainant returned my call and advised that she did not witness
any of the reported concerns, but was advised of the concerns by
another individual that does not want to be named or contacted.
Complainant was not able to provide detailed information about
the suspected carpet burns on Youth A or witnessing staff attempt
to force drugs down the throat of youth at the facility. She advised
that she cannot confirm seeing bruises, burns or other marks on
the body of Youth A. Complainant was asked to provide my name
and contact information to the individual that has firsthand
knowledge of information and request that he give me a call. To
date I have not received a return call.
On 01/22/2025 contact was made with the assigned FCW for
Youth A via email. She denied having any concerns relative to
Youth A and her placement at Vista Maria.
The following interviews were completed on 1/23/2025 at
Vista Maria, unless otherwise noted.
Compliance was advised of the allegations associated with the
investigation. He confirmed the name and DOB of Youth A and
provided placement dates. He denied being advised of any
allegations involving Youth A. He denied their being any video
footage to review or Incident Reports involving physical discipline
or youth being forced to take medication.
An interview was completed with Youth A. She confirmed that
she has been placed at the facility since 2023 and has been at
Myriam Hall since July 2024. She reported feeling safe at the
facility and denied any concerns with staff. She denied having
any carpet burns on her body or having knowledge of any other
youth having carpet burns. Youth A denied knowledge of any
youth, including herself, having drugs forced down their throat.
2

She advised that she does take prescription medication but denies
that staff forces it down her throat.
An interview was completed with Supervisor 1, Staff 1 and Staff
2. All three denied seeing any carpet burns on Youth A or any
other residents in Myriam Hall. They also denied knowledge of
any staff forcing drugs down the throats of youth at the facility.
An interview was completed with Youth B and Youth C. Both
youth denied having any personal carpet burns and denied seeing
any carpet burns on Youth A or other youth. Both youth also
denied that drugs are being forced down the throat of youth at the
facility. They denied having knowledge or hearing of it occurring.
On 01/29/2025 a Placement Conference was held to discuss the
Placement of Youth A. FCW and PCW were a part of the
meeting. FCW again denied any concerns regarding placement of
Youth A and reported that Youth A denied having any carpet
burns or knowledge of staff forcing drugs down the throat of youth.
Tour of Facility:
A tour of Myriam Hall was completed on 1/23/2025. The facility
was in good condition and no concerns were noted.
Documents Reviewed:
Vista Maria Employee Behavior Policy - In order to promote
acceptable behavior at Vista Maria, employees are expected to
conduct themselves in a positive, professional and respectful
manner at all times in order to promote the therapeutic alliance
between the employee and the clients who are assigned into the
care of Vista Maria". The document indicates that Vista Maria
employee prohibited behaviors includes: "Engaging in any form of
sexual or other forms of harassing or bullying behavior", "abuse,
neglect or mismanagement of clients, co worker or visitor",
"immoral, violent or indecent conduct on Vista Maria property",
"giving or receiving gifts/items of value to or from clients without
immediate supervisor approval".
Analysis At the conclusion of the investigation, the agency was found to be
in compliance with the licensing rule. Both staff and youth were
interviewed and there was no evidence to support the allegations
to be true. Youth A specifically denied having bruises, carpet
burns or any other marks on her body.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
3

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules.
